Athletic Association Must Send Runners
to Meet in Order to Retain Its
Membership—Men Training
After Drill Is Over.

John C. Knipp & Sons

Six men of the J ohns Hopkins
track team are being trained to
participate in the Penn Relays on
April 28 and in the big annual
meet of the Intercollegiate Amateur Athletic Association of America, which occurs May 25 and 26.
Though this step is apparently
contrary to the recently adopted
policy of the General Athletic Association of suspending all athletics at Hopkins, that body
deemed it wise to permit the team
to take part in these two meets,
which are considered the biggest
events in the track world of this
country.
As it is the iron-bound rule of
the I. C. A. A. A. A. that its members shall send men at least once
in two years to take part, and as
Hopkins did not enter any men
last year, the Athletic Association
is obliged to send men to it-this
year, in order to retain its membership. Moreover, the men are
practicing at 6 o'clock, after battalion drill is over.
As long as the men were training it seemed expedient to enter a
team in the Penn Relays in which
practically all the big colleges
are
'
entered. In that meet, the team,
which will be picked from Captain Straus, Uhler, E. G. Hall,
Winslow, Weeks and Firor, will
run against Fordham, Columbia,
Georgetown and Pittsburgh.
Though Virginia is also entered in
this race, it is doubtful as to
whether it will compete. All these
colleges are entering fast teams,
the Fordham four being reputed
to- be among the best in the country.
Coach England is confident of a
very excellent showing, as the
Black and Blue men are being
rounded into splendid -form. It
may be remembered that Uhler
was one of the star performers of,
the team during the past four
years, that Weeks broke the South
Atlantic indoor two-mile record
at the George Washington University meet, that E. G. Hall won
the open handicap quarter mile in
the Georgetown meet and that
Captain Straus won the open half
mile in the same meet. Winslow
and Firor have also past achievements and are expected to bring
home points with the other four.
Hopkins is placed in Class 1,
just below the championships, in
the Penn Relays. In 1918 and
1914 Hopkins won its race, lost
in 1915 and did not compete in
1916.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 23, 1917.

5

James Joseph Sylvester,FirstHopkinsProfessor ofMathematics
EARLY LIFE SPENT IN ENGLAND
Educated at Cambridge—Came to America in 1841-63 Years Old When
Made Professor of Mathematics at Hopkins.

James Joseph Sylvester was
born .in London on - September 3,
1814, the youngest amohg several
brothers and sisters. His father's
name was Abraham Joseph, and
after the father's death the eldest
boy moved to America and assumed the name of Sylvester, all
the rest of the brothers following
the example.
Until he was fifteen years of
age, Sylvester was educated in
London, and it is said that even
at this time his gift for mathematics was very pronounced. In
1829 he went to Liverpool where
he attended the Royal Institute.
He only remained there for two
years, but during this time established his reputation as a brilliant
mathematician.
In 1831, when just over seven
teen, he entered St. John's College,
Cambridge. He continued here
until the beginning of 1834, when
sickness compelled him to leave
Ins work for a time. He re-entered
college in 1836 and took in final
examinations in 1837,being placed
second on the list.
In 1838 Sylvester was elected
to the professorship of natural
philosophy at (what is now) University College, London. While
here he also *as elected a Fellow
of the Royal Society and began to
publish articles on his chosen subject.
After three years he left the
Old World and took the, position
of professor of mathematics at tic'
University of Virginia. His e-;perience here was disheartening,
and almost caused him to give 11,)
mathematics. He was not understood, and his brilliant mind wAs
not given proper opportunities for
development. In addition, lie be
came involved in slavery disputes
with some of his students, and the
unpleasant feeling that developed
made his life almost unbearable.
The outcome was his immediate
return to England where he took
a position as actuary with a life
assurance company. He remained
at this post for ten years before
again returning to the teaching of
mathematics. In 1855 he was ap
pointed professor of mathmalics
at the Royal Military Academy.
Woolwich, which position he held
for fifteen years.
In 1875 he was chosen to head
the department of mathematics in
the newly founded Johns Honkinq
1Thiversity. He remained at Ho-)kins until 1883. when. w*th
praise and gratitude or his colleagues in America rilwing, in his
ears, he recrossed the Atlantic to
become Savilian professor of geometry at Oxford.

"You can not have a great university without such great
men as Sylvester in your corps of teachers," wrote Prof. Benjamin Pierce to President Gilman, before the Johns Hopkins
University had been formally launched. "I hope you will find
it in your heart to place him where he belongs, and the time
will come when all the world will applaud the wisdom of your
selection."
President Gilman did find it in his heart to follow the advice—
and Professor Pierce's prophecy has been fulfilled. The name
of Sylvester today is among the greatest of all the great names
which have adorned Hopkins' history. Coming to Baltimore a
stranger at the age of sixty-three, Sylvester, nevertheless, supported the ideals of the new university with a vigor and an enthusiasm unsurpassed by the youngest of his associates.
It is not in the work he did, however, that Sylvester is alone
interesting. The peculiarities of the man—his marvelous erudition and sympathy with all branches of intellectual achievement, his keen interest in all things esthetic, the brilliancy of
his attack upon the outworn narrowness of the English universities to which Hopkins was setting a new example, all give to
his character a peculiar vividness. He brought to the University a touch of the Old World atmosphere; he personified the
combination of venerable traditions with ever-youthful energy.

mathematics, he had a paralytic in writing verse, among his .conseizure from which he never re- tributions being "Rosalind" and
"Spring's Debut, a Town Idyll."

WORK HAD WORLD INFLUENCE
Made Hopkins a Center of Mathematical
Research—Inspired Pupils With His
Zeal - First Editor of American
Journal of Mathematics.

When the Johns Hopkins University was founded at Baltimore
in 1875, James Sylvester was
chosen as the first professor of
mathematics. He was given freerein and allowed to conduct his
department as he saw fit. He
had taught for a year at the University of Virginia, but he had
not been appreciated there, and
after his distasteful experience
and hasty return to England from
Virginia, he ventured again to the
New World with pronounced
misgivings. At Hopkins, however,
lie was allowed the perfect free(:0111 needed to bring out the full
force of his character and ability.
All during his stay at Hopkins,
Sylvester emphasized what he believed to be the ideal method of
teaching — the combination instruction and research. It was
while teaching one of his pupils
the "New Algebra" that Sylvester
had an inspiration which eventually led to his discovery of the
proof of ,principles whose solution he had given up as hopeless.
When the American Journal a
Mathematics was established at
the University in 1878, it was put
under the direction of Professor
Sylvester. The first article he
published in the Journal was an
account of the application of the
new atomic theory to the graphical representation of the concomitants of binary quantities.
During his stay at Hopkins,
Fylvester, besides accomplishing a
vast amount of mathematical research work, was an inspiring
teacher. His ardor for his subject never waned. In the classroom his enthusiasm would invariably kindle, and he would lose
himself in his work; his mind, although he was almost seventy,
ever active, ever searching for
new principles. At times, in the
course of a lecture, he would suddenly see some new problem, leave
the subject he happened to be
teaching, and work away on the
new train of inquiry until the problem was solved. By carrying on his
investigations and researches before his class, he instilled into the
students a desire to do such work
for themselves, besides showing
them the methods pursued by the
skilled investigator.
When Professor Sylvester decided to leave the new University
that Ile had assisted so much, the
president called a farewell meeting in his honor on December 20,
1883, at which meeting the follow(Continued on page 6, col. 3)

* * * Of his work as a teacher,
I can speak only upon the basis
of his activity in this University.
The one thing which constantly
marked his lectures was enthusiastic love of the thing he was do
ing. He had in the fullest possible degree, to use the Ftench
phrase, the defect of this quality;
for as he almost always spoke
with -enthusiastic ardor, so it was
almost never possible for him to
speak on • matters incapable of
evoking his ardor. In other
words, the substance of his lectures had to consist largely •of
his own work, and, as a rule, of
work hot from the forge. The
consequence was that a continuous and systematic presentation
of any extensive body of doctrine
already completed was not to be
expected from him. Any unsolved
difficulty; any suggested extension, such as would have been
passed by with a mention by other
lecturers, became with him inevitably the occasion of a digression
which was sure to consume many
weeks, if, indeed, it did not take
him away from the original subject permanently. Nearly all of
the important memoirs which he
published while in Baltimore
arose in this way. We who attended his lectures may be said to
have seen these memoirs in the
making. He would give us on the
Friday the outcome of his grapplings with the enemy since the
Tuesday lecture. Rarely can it
have fallen to the lot of any
class to follow so completely the
workings of the mind of the master.

an extraordinary faculty for the
coinage of words, which, indeed,

keen sense for language in gen
eral. In this matter of the coinage of words, he doubtless went

things; but there can be no question of the great service he rendered to the new science of invariants by the creation of a whole

thought in what would otherwise

On Wednesday, at 12.30 1'. Al.,
in the lecture-room of the Mechanical Engineering Building,
the Class of 1917 will consider a
plan worked out by the coMmittee
appointed by President Sutton at
the senior banquet to raise a fund
of $25,000 for the University within the next twenty years.
The delay in the execution of
-the idea conceived that night has
been due to the fact that the class
has been considering the advisability of two opposing plans—one,
to raise the fund by means of regular endowment insurance policies;
the other, to raise it by each man
pledging himself to pay a certain
sum into the fund every year for
twenty years.
After a careful personal canvass, the members of the committee have found the sentiment of
the class to be almost unanimously
in favor of the second plan. Several strong arguments are advanced to show why this method
of raising the fund would be far
better than putting the matter
.into the hands of an insurance
company.
In the first place, it is argued
by those in favor of the second
plan, that paying the money directly into the fund will, with the
same amount of annual payments,
result in a far larger fund. In the
second place, the class, almost to a
man, would rather pay their
Money directly into the fund than
create the fund indirectly through
the medium of a company. In.the
third place, it is pointed out • that
the payments to which the men
pledge themselves can be graded—
six dollars the first year after
graduation, eight the second, ten
the third, and so on. In this manner the payments will bear a direct
relation to the probable growth of
earning power of the members of
the class. It is estimated that the
men can pay forty dollars far
more easily twenty years after
they have been graduated than
they can twenty-five next year,
when the results of their education will not have had time to
manifest themselves in concrete
form.
The Endowment Fund Committee, consisting of Edward M. Stuart (chairman), Paul W. Sutton
and Reuben Oppenheimer, in view
of the unmistakable sentiment of
the class, after consultation with
the departments of -economics and
mathematics, has worked .• out a
plan which it believes in actual

[THE NEWS-LETTER publishes the following extracts from the New York
Times Magazine of April 15, 1917, in
order to bring to the attention of Hopkins men a somewhat radical departure
from the traditional American college.
Unfortunately, the limits of space prevent the giving of more than a general
Idea of the nature of this college,
which; incidentally, has attracted far
wider attention than its present enrollment of 252 would indicate. The
underlying idea of the institution,
however, is the simple premise that,
in a college, intellectual enthusiasm
should be as dominant in practice as
It is in theory. THE NEWS-LETTER invites its readers to state their views
as to whether or not the type of college which Reed introduces should
supplant the type to which it is opposed.—EDIT0R.]

have adopted the orthography of
the Simplified Spelling Board.
Many have done their best to be
of practical service to the communities in which they are situated.
"In none of these particulars is
Reed College unique, but it does
seem to be unique in the spirit
which is apparently in some cases
a cause and in others an effect of
the factors recorded above, and
which has resulted, in the words
of the President, 'in making
scholarship not only respectable
but necessary, and, as a rule, not
only necessary but attractive.' It
is only six years since Dr. William Trufant Foster, then professor of English and argumentation in Bowdoin College, was
elected president of Reed, with
power to invent a college spirit
and create traditions from the
ground up and after five years
Reed College has already a solid
record of achievementand has developed as well a college life in whose
flavor, as it appears to an alien
who studies it only from the publications of the college or the students, the crusading zeal for
simplified spelling, for instance,
appears to be quite as characteristic an element as the general interest in practical sociology.
"'It seemed to me,' says President Foster, in describing the
foundation of the college, 'that we
could probably perform no greater
service for the educational world
than to use the endowment provided by the Reed family in an attempt to establish a college in
which intellectual enthusiasm
should be dominant.
"No one, I think, acquainted
with this institution and with
others is inclined to question the
fact that there is far more persistent and serious study at Reed
College today than would have
been possible had intellectual interests been obliged to compete
with the distractions that commonly accompany the highly organized and expensive athletic
and social functions of American
colleges. There are those who believe that Reed College is missing
something that other colleges have
because of these outside activities,
and there are a few who believe
that the loss is serious. But even
these people are ready to admit
that the college has gained a large
measure of intellectual enthusiasm among its students, for which
the sacrifices of certain aspects of
college life were deliberately made
at the outset.'"

"Last June saw the completion
of the fifth college year and the
graduation of the second class by
Reed College of Portland, Oregon,
an institution which deserves, if
ally college deserves it, the much
misapplied adjective unique. There
are many peculiarities about Reed
College, or things that the conventional educator and the conventionally educated would regard
as peculiarities, but it is the combination of these features rather
than any single one that makes
the college distinctive.
"Practically all of the 600 odd
colleges and universities in the
United States are dedicated, theoretically, to the proposition that
intellectual progress and the creation or fostering of an enthusiasm.
for the intellectual life are the
prime purpose of an institution of
learning. Many colleges, to promote this or for other reasons,
have abolished fraternities, or
done away with intercollegiate
athletics. Several • colleges have
irregular requirements for admission, depending more on estimates
of the personal character and
ability of the candidate than on
examinations or certificates. At
least one, besides Reed, requires a
thesis embodying the results of
original research from candidates
for the baccalaureate degree, instead of reserving this for purely
graduate work.
"Many colleges have fairly complete honor systems, and various
forms of student self-government.
Not a few small colleges attempt
to discourage applicants for admission with the object of finally
admitting only those whose determination to pursue the things
best attainable at that particular

Y. M. C. A. COMMITTEES SELECTED

HOPKINS MAN BROWN PROFESSOR

President Swartz Announces Men Who
Will Direct Various Activities of
the Association Throughout
the Coming Year.

Dr. St: George L. Sioussat, an Alumnus
of 1896, Appointed Littlefield Professor of American History at
Brown University.

President William H. Swartz,
of the Y. M. C. A., has announced
the appointment of most of the
committee chairmen for the coming year. They are as follows:
Deputation Work — Frank W.
Sutton,'18.
Social Service Work—Allan K.
Chalmers, '18. s
Membership—Warner, '18.
Social—Walter L. Taylor,'18.
Bible Study—Roszel C. Thomsen, '19.
Chapel—Warren Almy,'20.
Music—McCleary, '20.
Mission Study—T. Terry Burger, '20.
New Student — Douglas Coulter, '20.
Reading Room — William L.
Merrilien, '20.
These men, together with the
newly elected officers, will form
the Y. M. C. A. cabinet for the
coming year. One or two other
chairmen will be appointed in the
near future to take charge of the
handbook, and 'other matters not
already provided for.
A joint meeting of the new
cabinet, this year's cabinet, and
the advisory board, will be held
shortly at the Hopkins Club.
There the old officers and chairmen will give the new men some
pointers as to the work, and the
general outlook for next year will
be discussed.

. St. George Leakin Sioussat, Ph.
D., a Johns Hopkins graduate, has
been appointed to the Littlefield
professorship of American history
at Brown University.
Dr. Sioussat received his bachelor of arts degree here in 189.6 ad
his doctor's degree in 1899. He
was assistant and instructor in
history at Smith College from 1899
to 1904, and professor of economics and history at the University
of the South from 1904 to 1911, being dean of the college of arts
and sciences during the last two
years of that time. Since 1911,
Dr. Sioussat has been professor of
history at Vanderbilt University.
In addition, he has held various
teaching positions at summer sessions of different universities,
teaching here in the summers of
1911 and 1912; has been active in
many educational and civic societies, has contributed valuable articles on historical subjects to
many periodicals and is the author
of several volumes along similar
lines.

Athletic Association Must Send Runners
to Meet in Order to Retain Its
Membership—Men Training
After Drill Is Over.

John C. Knipp & Sons

Six men of the J ohns Hopkins
track team are being trained to
participate in the Penn Relays on
April 28 and in the big annual
meet of the Intercollegiate Amateur Athletic Association of America, which occurs May 25 and 26.
Though this step is apparently
contrary to the recently adopted
policy of the General Athletic Association of suspending all athletics at Hopkins, that body
deemed it wise to permit the team
to take part in these two meets,
which are considered the biggest
events in the track world of this
country.
As it is the iron-bound rule of
the I. C. A. A. A. A. that its members shall send men at least once
in two years to take part, and as
Hopkins did not enter any men
last year, the Athletic Association
is obliged to send men to it-this
year, in order to retain its membership. Moreover, the men are
practicing at 6 o'clock, after battalion drill is over.
As long as the men were training it seemed expedient to enter a
team in the Penn Relays in which
practically all the big colleges
are
'
entered. In that meet, the team,
which will be picked from Captain Straus, Uhler, E. G. Hall,
Winslow, Weeks and Firor, will
run against Fordham, Columbia,
Georgetown and Pittsburgh.
Though Virginia is also entered in
this race, it is doubtful as to
whether it will compete. All these
colleges are entering fast teams,
the Fordham four being reputed
to- be among the best in the country.
Coach England is confident of a
very excellent showing, as the
Black and Blue men are being
rounded into splendid -form. It
may be remembered that Uhler
was one of the star performers of,
the team during the past four
years, that Weeks broke the South
Atlantic indoor two-mile record
at the George Washington University meet, that E. G. Hall won
the open handicap quarter mile in
the Georgetown meet and that
Captain Straus won the open half
mile in the same meet. Winslow
and Firor have also past achievements and are expected to bring
home points with the other four.
Hopkins is placed in Class 1,
just below the championships, in
the Penn Relays. In 1918 and
1914 Hopkins won its race, lost
in 1915 and did not compete in
1916.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 23, 1917.

5

James Joseph Sylvester,FirstHopkinsProfessor ofMathematics
EARLY LIFE SPENT IN ENGLAND
Educated at Cambridge—Came to America in 1841-63 Years Old When
Made Professor of Mathematics at Hopkins.

James Joseph Sylvester was
born .in London on - September 3,
1814, the youngest amohg several
brothers and sisters. His father's
name was Abraham Joseph, and
after the father's death the eldest
boy moved to America and assumed the name of Sylvester, all
the rest of the brothers following
the example.
Until he was fifteen years of
age, Sylvester was educated in
London, and it is said that even
at this time his gift for mathematics was very pronounced. In
1829 he went to Liverpool where
he attended the Royal Institute.
He only remained there for two
years, but during this time established his reputation as a brilliant
mathematician.
In 1831, when just over seven
teen, he entered St. John's College,
Cambridge. He continued here
until the beginning of 1834, when
sickness compelled him to leave
Ins work for a time. He re-entered
college in 1836 and took in final
examinations in 1837,being placed
second on the list.
In 1838 Sylvester was elected
to the professorship of natural
philosophy at (what is now) University College, London. While
here he also *as elected a Fellow
of the Royal Society and began to
publish articles on his chosen subject.
After three years he left the
Old World and took the, position
of professor of mathematics at tic'
University of Virginia. His e-;perience here was disheartening,
and almost caused him to give 11,)
mathematics. He was not understood, and his brilliant mind wAs
not given proper opportunities for
development. In addition, lie be
came involved in slavery disputes
with some of his students, and the
unpleasant feeling that developed
made his life almost unbearable.
The outcome was his immediate
return to England where he took
a position as actuary with a life
assurance company. He remained
at this post for ten years before
again returning to the teaching of
mathematics. In 1855 he was ap
pointed professor of mathmalics
at the Royal Military Academy.
Woolwich, which position he held
for fifteen years.
In 1875 he was chosen to head
the department of mathematics in
the newly founded Johns Honkinq
1Thiversity. He remained at Ho-)kins until 1883. when. w*th
praise and gratitude or his colleagues in America rilwing, in his
ears, he recrossed the Atlantic to
become Savilian professor of geometry at Oxford.

"You can not have a great university without such great
men as Sylvester in your corps of teachers," wrote Prof. Benjamin Pierce to President Gilman, before the Johns Hopkins
University had been formally launched. "I hope you will find
it in your heart to place him where he belongs, and the time
will come when all the world will applaud the wisdom of your
selection."
President Gilman did find it in his heart to follow the advice—
and Professor Pierce's prophecy has been fulfilled. The name
of Sylvester today is among the greatest of all the great names
which have adorned Hopkins' history. Coming to Baltimore a
stranger at the age of sixty-three, Sylvester, nevertheless, supported the ideals of the new university with a vigor and an enthusiasm unsurpassed by the youngest of his associates.
It is not in the work he did, however, that Sylvester is alone
interesting. The peculiarities of the man—his marvelous erudition and sympathy with all branches of intellectual achievement, his keen interest in all things esthetic, the brilliancy of
his attack upon the outworn narrowness of the English universities to which Hopkins was setting a new example, all give to
his character a peculiar vividness. He brought to the University a touch of the Old World atmosphere; he personified the
combination of venerable traditions with ever-youthful energy.

Sylvester, in the latter part of
In March, 1897, while still actively working upon his beloved his life, made several experiments
mathematics, he had a paralytic in writing verse, among his .conseizure from which he never re- tributions being "Rosalind" and
"Spring's Debut, a Town Idyll."

JAMES JOSEPH SYLVESTER

WORK HAD WORLD INFLUENCE
Made Hopkins a Center of Mathematical
Research—Inspired Pupils With His
Zeal - First Editor of American
Journal of Mathematics.

When the Johns Hopkins University was founded at Baltimore
in 1875, James Sylvester was
chosen as the first professor of
mathematics. He was given freerein and allowed to conduct his
department as he saw fit. He
had taught for a year at the University of Virginia, but he had
not been appreciated there, and
after his distasteful experience
and hasty return to England from
Virginia, he ventured again to the
New World with pronounced
misgivings. At Hopkins, however,
lie was allowed the perfect free(:0111 needed to bring out the full
force of his character and ability.
All during his stay at Hopkins,
Sylvester emphasized what he believed to be the ideal method of
teaching — the combination instruction and research. It was
while teaching one of his pupils
the "New Algebra" that Sylvester
had an inspiration which eventually led to his discovery of the
proof of ,principles whose solution he had given up as hopeless.
When the American Journal a
Mathematics was established at
the University in 1878, it was put
under the direction of Professor
Sylvester. The first article he
published in the Journal was an
account of the application of the
new atomic theory to the graphical representation of the concomitants of binary quantities.
During his stay at Hopkins,
Fylvester, besides accomplishing a
vast amount of mathematical research work, was an inspiring
teacher. His ardor for his subject never waned. In the classroom his enthusiasm would invariably kindle, and he would lose
himself in his work; his mind, although he was almost seventy,
ever active, ever searching for
new principles. At times, in the
course of a lecture, he would suddenly see some new problem, leave
the subject he happened to be
teaching, and work away on the
new train of inquiry until the problem was solved. By carrying on his
investigations and researches before his class, he instilled into the
students a desire to do such work
for themselves, besides showing
them the methods pursued by the
skilled investigator.
When Professor Sylvester decided to leave the new University
that Ile had assisted so much, the
president called a farewell meeting in his honor on December 20,
1883, at which meeting the follow(Continued on page 6, col. 3)

* * * Of his work as a teacher,
I can speak only upon the basis
of his activity in this University.
The one thing which constantly
marked his lectures was enthusiastic love of the thing he was do
ing. He had in the fullest possible degree, to use the Ftench
phrase, the defect of this quality;
for as he almost always spoke
with -enthusiastic ardor, so it was
almost never possible for him to
speak on • matters incapable of
evoking his ardor. In other
words, the substance of his lectures had to consist largely •of
his own work, and, as a rule, of
work hot from the forge. The
consequence was that a continuous and systematic presentation
of any extensive body of doctrine
already completed was not to be
expected from him. Any unsolved
difficulty; any suggested extension, such as would have been
passed by with a mention by other
lecturers, became with him inevitably the occasion of a digression
which was sure to consume many
weeks, if, indeed, it did not take
him away from the original subject permanently. Nearly all of
the important memoirs which he
published while in Baltimore
arose in this way. We who attended his lectures may be said to
have seen these memoirs in the
making. He would give us on the
Friday the outcome of his grapplings with the enemy since the
Tuesday lecture. Rarely can it
have fallen to the lot of any
class to follow so completely the
workings of the mind of the master.

an extraordinary faculty for the
coinage of words, which, indeed,
was merely a part of remarkable
keen sense for language in gen
eral. In this matter of the coinage of words, he doubtless went
to extremes, as he did in other
things; but there can be no question of the great service he rendered to the new science of invariants by the creation of a whole
new vocabulary which rendere.1
possible the crystallization of
thought in what would otherwise
have been a comparatively amoropitons mass. There are doubtless
other departments of mathematics
which would have been more manageable by the skillful application
of just such a naine-creating faculty. Any mathematical conception with which Sylvester had

with the very greatest; but his
work, brilliant and memorable- as
it was, affords no trpe measure of
his intellectual greatness. Those
who came within the sphere of
his personality could not but feel
that, through the force of circumstances, combined with the peculiarities of his poetic temperament, his performances, splendid
as it was, had not adequately reflected his magnificent powers.
Those of us who were connected
with
with him cherish his memory as
that of a sympathetic friend and
a generous critic. And in this
University, as lot* as it shall exist, he will be remembered as the
man whose genius illuminated its
years, and whose devotion and ardor furnished the most inspiring
of all the elements which went to
make those years so memorable

On Wednesday, at 12.30 1'. Al.,
in the lecture-room of the Mechanical Engineering Building,
the Class of 1917 will consider a
plan worked out by the coMmittee
appointed by President Sutton at
the senior banquet to raise a fund
of $25,000 for the University within the next twenty years.
The delay in the execution of
-the idea conceived that night has
been due to the fact that the class
has been considering the advisability of two opposing plans—one,
to raise the fund by means of regular endowment insurance policies;
the other, to raise it by each man
pledging himself to pay a certain
sum into the fund every year for
twenty years.
After a careful personal canvass, the members of the committee have found the sentiment of
the class to be almost unanimously
in favor of the second plan. Several strong arguments are advanced to show why this method
of raising the fund would be far
better than putting the matter
.into the hands of an insurance
company.
In the first place, it is argued
by those in favor of the second
plan, that paying the money directly into the fund will, with the
same amount of annual payments,
result in a far larger fund. In the
second place, the class, almost to a
man, would rather pay their
Money directly into the fund than
create the fund indirectly through
the medium of a company. In.the
third place, it is pointed out • that
the payments to which the men
pledge themselves can be graded—
six dollars the first year after
graduation, eight the second, ten
the third, and so on. In this manner the payments will bear a direct
relation to the probable growth of
earning power of the members of
the class. It is estimated that the
men can pay forty dollars far
more easily twenty years after
they have been graduated than
they can twenty-five next year,
when the results of their education will not have had time to
manifest themselves in concrete
form.
The Endowment Fund Committee, consisting of Edward M. Stuart (chairman), Paul W. Sutton
and Reuben Oppenheimer, in view
of the unmistakable sentiment of
the class, after consultation with
the departments of -economics and
mathematics, has worked .• out a
plan which it believes in actual

[THE NEWS-LETTER publishes the following extracts from the New York
Times Magazine of April 15, 1917, in
order to bring to the attention of Hopkins men a somewhat radical departure
from the traditional American college.
Unfortunately, the limits of space prevent the giving of more than a general
Idea of the nature of this college,
which; incidentally, has attracted far
wider attention than its present enrollment of 252 would indicate. The
underlying idea of the institution,
however, is the simple premise that,
in a college, intellectual enthusiasm
should be as dominant in practice as
It is in theory. THE NEWS-LETTER invites its readers to state their views
as to whether or not the type of college which Reed introduces should
supplant the type to which it is opposed.—EDIT0R.]

have adopted the orthography of
the Simplified Spelling Board.
Many have done their best to be
of practical service to the communities in which they are situated.
"In none of these particulars is
Reed College unique, but it does
seem to be unique in the spirit
which is apparently in some cases
a cause and in others an effect of
the factors recorded above, and
which has resulted, in the words
of the President, 'in making
scholarship not only respectable
but necessary, and, as a rule, not
only necessary but attractive.' It
is only six years since Dr. William Trufant Foster, then professor of English and argumentation in Bowdoin College, was
elected president of Reed, with
power to invent a college spirit
and create traditions from the
ground up and after five years
Reed College has already a solid
record of achievementand has developed as well a college life in whose
flavor, as it appears to an alien
who studies it only from the publications of the college or the students, the crusading zeal for
simplified spelling, for instance,
appears to be quite as characteristic an element as the general interest in practical sociology.
"'It seemed to me,' says President Foster, in describing the
foundation of the college, 'that we
could probably perform no greater
service for the educational world
than to use the endowment provided by the Reed family in an attempt to establish a college in
which intellectual enthusiasm
should be dominant.
"No one, I think, acquainted
with this institution and with
others is inclined to question the
fact that there is far more persistent and serious study at Reed
College today than would have
been possible had intellectual interests been obliged to compete
with the distractions that commonly accompany the highly organized and expensive athletic
and social functions of American
colleges. There are those who believe that Reed College is missing
something that other colleges have
because of these outside activities,
and there are a few who believe
that the loss is serious. But even
these people are ready to admit
that the college has gained a large
measure of intellectual enthusiasm among its students, for which
the sacrifices of certain aspects of
college life were deliberately made
at the outset.'"

"Last June saw the completion
of the fifth college year and the
graduation of the second class by
Reed College of Portland, Oregon,
an institution which deserves, if
ally college deserves it, the much
misapplied adjective unique. There
are many peculiarities about Reed
College, or things that the conventional educator and the conventionally educated would regard
as peculiarities, but it is the combination of these features rather
than any single one that makes
the college distinctive.
"Practically all of the 600 odd
colleges and universities in the
United States are dedicated, theoretically, to the proposition that
intellectual progress and the creation or fostering of an enthusiasm.
for the intellectual life are the
prime purpose of an institution of
learning. Many colleges, to promote this or for other reasons,
have abolished fraternities, or
done away with intercollegiate
athletics. Several • colleges have
irregular requirements for admission, depending more on estimates
of the personal character and
ability of the candidate than on
examinations or certificates. At
least one, besides Reed, requires a
thesis embodying the results of
original research from candidates
for the baccalaureate degree, instead of reserving this for purely
graduate work.
"Many colleges have fairly complete honor systems, and various
forms of student self-government.
Not a few small colleges attempt
to discourage applicants for admission with the object of finally
admitting only those whose determination to pursue the things
best attainable at that particular

Y. M. C. A. COMMITTEES SELECTED

HOPKINS MAN BROWN PROFESSOR

President Swartz Announces Men Who
Will Direct Various Activities of
the Association Throughout
the Coming Year.

Dr. St: George L. Sioussat, an Alumnus
of 1896, Appointed Littlefield Professor of American History at
Brown University.

President William H. Swartz,
of the Y. M. C. A., has announced
the appointment of most of the
committee chairmen for the coming year. They are as follows:
Deputation Work — Frank W.
Sutton,'18.
Social Service Work—Allan K.
Chalmers, '18. s
Membership—Warner, '18.
Social—Walter L. Taylor,'18.
Bible Study—Roszel C. Thomsen, '19.
Chapel—Warren Almy,'20.
Music—McCleary, '20.
Mission Study—T. Terry Burger, '20.
New Student — Douglas Coulter, '20.
Reading Room — William L.
Merrilien, '20.
These men, together with the
newly elected officers, will form
the Y. M. C. A. cabinet for the
coming year. One or two other
chairmen will be appointed in the
near future to take charge of the
handbook, and 'other matters not
already provided for.
A joint meeting of the new
cabinet, this year's cabinet, and
the advisory board, will be held
shortly at the Hopkins Club.
There the old officers and chairmen will give the new men some
pointers as to the work, and the
general outlook for next year will
be discussed.

. St. George Leakin Sioussat, Ph.
D., a Johns Hopkins graduate, has
been appointed to the Littlefield
professorship of American history
at Brown University.
Dr. Sioussat received his bachelor of arts degree here in 189.6 ad
his doctor's degree in 1899. He
was assistant and instructor in
history at Smith College from 1899
to 1904, and professor of economics and history at the University
of the South from 1904 to 1911, being dean of the college of arts
and sciences during the last two
years of that time. Since 1911,
Dr. Sioussat has been professor of
history at Vanderbilt University.
In addition, he has held various
teaching positions at summer sessions of different universities,
teaching here in the summers of
1911 and 1912; has been active in
many educational and civic societies, has contributed valuable articles on historical subjects to
many periodicals and is the author
of several volumes along similar
lines.
